comment.body:
Please look at most of our tests. They are simple straight forward. This is important for readability. Your tests have way too many functions calling other functions and so it is not clear what exactly is being tested.

Also the tests should be

it('should do a specific thing'...) not _itWorksForM2E

What are these if(!SKIP)

We should not have if statements in the tests. Tests should be linear set of things. Ifs and loops are tricky because it is very easy to get them to fail in a way that tests actually don't do anything.

Note that there could be other characters like a dot, or a hyphen in the file names that have special meanings in the Regex. Hence, we would need to escape the regex. The alternative would be to not use the toMatch method, and instead just use string.match method.

issue.title: Angular Profile Mode + Caching tools (ngRepeat default behavior issue)

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description:
Holds the backlog of issues and pull requests that have been triaged.

Before assigning items to this milestone they should be labelled, at the very least with the correct "type" label (i.e. "issue", "pr", "bug", "regression", "chore", "docs", etc).  Preferably you should also check for duplicate issues/PRs, note CLA status and assign "complexity" and "impact" labels too.

issue.body:
This subject may be a bit controversial, but I hope someone will share my idea.
I think Angular should have built in profile module or good toolkit for that, which would report slow parts of user defined code (ignoring core modules) or parts of templates in angular way (preserving scope hierarchy and similar things).

Also I request to disable some of default caching, like in ngRepeat. And this is the controversial part.
Why you ask? Shouldn't it be blazing fast out of the box? My answer is NO! It should be working correctly, this is main goal!
I was doing very simple paginator, for big project with dynamically loaded modules using requirejs. Very simple, just ng-repat="p for pages" then ng-class="{current: p == page}", and it doesn't work correctly! It start desynchronize after heavy use, because of internal caching. Adding "track by p + '_' + page" solved issue, but developers spent quite some time to find what was not working, and caching in that place wasn't really needed, as it wasn't really expensive to rerender it.
Caching should be explicit, enabled on demand (for example by using track by). I think there is enough magic for simple programmer that he need to deal with using angularjs.

In addition, there should be available easy caching tools and support for them in directives. This would solve most of performance problems which are currently solved in same way but using external tools.

comment.body: Yes, I'm using it, but as you said :) it's not perfect.
Our style is to keep it methods in the describe. Currently this style is confusing since it is not clear what exactly is being teste. From within the it you are free to call helper methods.

issue.title: debug broken on 0.19.0 but works on 0.18.1
issue.body:
I'm unable to debug on protractor 0.19.0
> Failed to open socket on port 5858, waiting 1000 ms before retrying

Downgraded to protractor 0.18.1 and worked fine!
Then re-installed 0.19.0 to test again, and the same socket error.

Tested on chrome33 & firefox27, chromedriver 2.9. node 0.10.25
Using `webdriver-manager start` in another console.

```
$ protractor debug config/local/firefox.js
< debugger listening on port 5858
connecting... ok
break in /usr/local/lib/node_modules/protractor/lib/cli.js:7
  5  * Values from command line options override values from the config.
  6  */
  7 'use strict';
  8 
  9 // Coffee is required here to enable config files written in coffee-script.
debug> c
< ------------------------------------
< PID: 15196 (capability: firefoxANY #1)
< ------------------------------------
< debugger listening on port 5858
< Failed to open socket on port 5858, waiting 1000 ms before retrying
< Failed to open socket on port 5858, waiting 1000 ms before retrying
< Failed to open socket on port 5858, waiting 1000 ms before retrying
< Failed to open socket on port 5858, waiting 1000 ms before retrying
< Failed to open socket on port 5858, waiting 1000 ms before retrying
< Failed to open socket on port 5858, waiting 1000 ms before retrying
```

Then port 5858 seems to be left open:

```
$ sudo lsof -i tcp:5858
COMMAND   PID USER   FD   TYPE  DEVICE SIZE/OFF NODE NAME
node    15185 user   11u  IPv4 1397240      0t0  TCP localhost:58131->localhost:5858 (ESTABLISHED)
node    15187 user    9u  IPv4 1397907      0t0  TCP localhost:5858 (LISTEN)
node    15187 user   10u  IPv4 1395469      0t0  TCP localhost:5858->localhost:58131 (ESTABLISHED)
node    15196 user    9u  IPv4 1397907      0t0  TCP localhost:5858 (LISTEN)
node    15196 user   10u  IPv4 1395469      0t0  TCP localhost:5858->localhost:58131 (ESTABLISHED)
```

Please note debug works well when i re-install 0.18.1

Tried with a remote selenium grid, same issue so webdriver-manager is not related.

https://github.com/angular/protractor/issues/549 looks like a question but might be related.

comment.body: browser.debugger() is being ignored by protractor 0.20.1 on Windows 7 (node-debug 0.1.0)

issue.title: Feature request: support for observable
issue.body:
There is a lot effort going on to improve performance in Angular and
there are several situations where developers encounter problems (at least negative suprises) because some model changes are not recognized (collections) without some special effort.

Wouldn't it make sense to support something like the observableCollection as it is used in Polymer (https://pub.dartlang.org/packages/observe)? (found the source here https://chromium.googlesource.com/external/dart/+/refs/heads/master/dart/pkg/observe)
I haven't investigated how this works in detail but it is about collections (AFAIK currently only List/Map) that notify about being changed.

This could be extended by defining a pattern how every kind of object can notify Angular about changes by (e.g. implementing an interface ChangeNotifier or whatever).

As a next step I imagine an object using this pattern being able to notify the collection it is stored in about changes and the collection propagates it to parties interested in changes in the collection.

I think this could greatly improve developer experience without to much influence on the performance.

What do you think?

EDIT

seems this already covers this
[Layer 1: Object.observe Polyfill](https://docs.google.com/document/d/10W46qDNO8Dl0Uye3QX0oUDPYAwaPl0qNy73TVLjd1WI/edit#heading=h.x26w6vayy55n)

comment.body: If `observe` turns out to be insufficient, please re-open this issue.

issue.title: Fix problem with Jasmine and afterEach

comment.body: @jbdeboer turns out that our afterEatch did not run.

Currently, JQuery does two things that we need to keep:
-> html() which hides the "ng-binding" TaggingCompiler implementation details
-> textWithShadow() which hides the shadow DOM in components

The rest of JQuery's methods are simple wrappers around Element

issue.title: Please publish AngularJS as an NPM module

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description:
Holds the backlog of issues and pull requests that have been triaged.

Before assigning items to this milestone they should be labelled, at the very least with the correct "type" label (i.e. "issue", "pr", "bug", "regression", "chore", "docs", etc).  Preferably you should also check for duplicate issues/PRs, note CLA status and assign "complexity" and "impact" labels too.

issue.body:
It just takes a few minutes to publish an npm module of the existing AngularJS project, but it would accomplish the following:

* Enable deployment from the standard infrastructure being used for both server and client Javascript code
* Enable browserify users like me to package up client side libraries I fetch with npm (though in production, I reference a copy on the CDN)
* Find new Angular releases using npm outdated.
* Jump ahead of jQuery, which is in the process of taking over the npm management of their library: https://github.com/coolaj86/node-jquery/issues/56

The npm name angularjs remains available. I recommend mapping it to git://github.com/angular/angular.js.git#v1.0.x and perhaps also creating an angularjs-unstable which pulls from master.

Thanks!

comment.body:
Turns out; I didn't want this whole repo; just the built output!

So, I wrote a script... Until there are official packages, you can get the build output (taken from code.angularjs.org) from this repo:

https://github.com/DanTup/angular-builds/

There is a branch for each version of Angular published to code.angularjs.org, and each branch has a readme showing the npm command for that version. For example, the latest beta readme is here:

https://github.com/DanTup/angular-builds/tree/1.3.0-beta.2

and the npm command to install is

    npm install https://github.com/DanTup/angular-builds/tarball/1.3.0-beta.2 --save-dev

You can see a full list of branches/versions here:

https://github.com/DanTup/angular-builds/branches

Hope this might be useful to others until there are official packages.

issue.title: ngOptions can cause flickering/jumping highlight on Firefox
issue.body:
**Request Type**: bug

**How to reproduce**: http://plnkr.co/edit/ciOEcE9fidbeXzRrZ2HN?p=preview

**Component(s)**: ngOptions

**Impact**: medium

**Complexity**: small

**Detailed Description**:
The ngOptions directive causes a strange flickering behavior on Firefox when the digest loop is triggered. This issue does not occur for Safari or Chrome. I encountered this issue in version 1.2.14 but after researching, I believe it's been around since version 1.0.x.

**Other Comments**:
I was able to "fix" this issue by editing `src/ng/directive/select.js` line 534 as follows:
```diff
-                if (lastElement[0].selected !== option.selected) {
+                if (existingOption.selected !== option.selected) {
```
Unfortunately this breaks on of the select unit tests, *should select correct input if previously selected option was "?"*.

I'll play with it some more but would welcome any input from the community.

comment.body: @Narretz I just applied that fix to my local checkout of `v1.2.x`. Tested in Firefox and also ran `grunt test`. Fix seemed to work for both!

issue.title: Limit the number of exported symbols from angular libraries
issue.body: `package:angular/angular.dart` is exporting too many unnecessary symbols which sometime clash with other user-defined and 3rd-party symbols. For instance, `NullTreeSanitizer` is commonly used.

issue.title: [WIP] chore(Hop build process)
issue.body:
This is a research project to see if the Hop library (https://github.com/dart-lang/hop) would be a good candidate to automate the build process in a platform agnostic way.  This was inspired by @bgourlie and issue #482. I implemented just enough of the build process to get a conversation going, the unit testing is not implemented, but from what I've seen so far I'm pretty confident it can be done.  An alternate approach to this would be to use Gulp, which is what I'm going to experiment with next.

Please take a few minutes to check it out and share your opinions.  Thanks!

Test it out with the following commands:

dart tool/hop_runner.dart build_debug
dart tool/hop_runner.dart build_release
dart tool/hop_runner.dart analyze_libs
dart tool/hop_runner.dart all_debug
dart tool/hop_runner.dart all_release

comment.body: I haven't used neither hop nor grinder but according to this comment grinder might be a good fit too. https://github.com/dart-gde/chrome.dart/issues/160

issue.title: alternate $watch for multiple values
issue.body:
I propose adding another syntax for `$watch`:

```
$scope.$watch(['prop', 'foo.bar'], fn);
```

which would mean the same thing as:

```
$scope.$watch('prop', fn);
$scope.$watch('foo.bar', fn);
```

Currently, it's possible to do the same thing using `$watchCollection`, however:

- `$watchCollection` supports arbitrary collections; multi-`$watch` can be optimized better because it's always watching an array, whose size is fixed
- writing the array inside of a string (`'[prop, foo.bar]'`) looks kludgy

But I think the reason for having multi-`$watch` is mainly semantics (i.e. better communication of intent):

- `$watch(['a', 'b'], fn)`: fn depends on multiple things: `a` and `b`
- `$watchCollection('collection', fn)`: fn depends on the _contents_ of one thing: `collection`
